text:
I'm running Apache httpd 2.0.46 on RHEL 3, and I couldn't get the xbithack to work no matter 
what I did with the configuration. Finally, I discovered that if I didn't name my file with .html or any 
other known type, then the xbithack worked (i.e. test.junk instead of test.html). So instead of 
limiting xbithack to only html files, mod_include actually rejects all html files. I went into 
mod_include.c and changed a line in the include_fixup method:
if (!r->content_type || strcmp(r->content_type, "text/html")) {
to
if (!r->content_type || !strcmp(r->content_type, "text/html")) {
Then I recompiled the module and substituted it for the one RHEL 3 came with, and now it all 
works like the documentation says it should. I just downloaded the v. 2.0.52 source code from 
Apache and looked at it's mod_include.c code, and it's the same way, although I can't say from 
experience if it behaves the same or not.
creator: wannajava@cedarcomm.com

text:
The problem is probably that the .html files were not getting configured with
the text/html MIME type - had you deactivated mod_mime_magic, perhaps?   Check
what Content-Type was actually returned by the server for these pages. 

The unchanged code is correct here and it works fine in both vanilla 2.0.52 and
RHEL3/httpd here.
creator: jorton@redhat.com
jorton@redhat.com
text: I meant mod_mime not mod_mime_magic but either way...

The problem was not the .html content type. It turns out it was the character
encoding. I had html pages that didn't look right using the UTF-8 default, so I
had added to httpd.conf the line:

AddCharset ISO-8859-1 .html .htm

Apparently, xbithack didn't like it. I've now deleted that line and changed the
default line to:

AddDefaultCharset ISO-8859-1

Then I put back the old mod_include.so, and it works fine. My mistake.
creator: wannajava@cedarcomm.com
